YOUR WARDROBE
Fanning is the key to a successiu and practical travel
wardrobe. Plan your wardrobe around one of the basic
colors - "accessories with belts, scarves, costume
jewelry of different hues - avoid fussy clothes. Frilly
things wrinkle badly! Avoid the too-full skirt or the
uncomforehle"sim.limskirt. Comforable shoes are
a must's hetter to break them in before vou leave
Your wardrobe will be determined largely by the cli.
mate of the countries you plan to visit. Wools for the
colder countries: cottons for the warmer climes. The
new miracle fabrics hold their creases and shed
WrInKleS. A chIC American woman builds her wardrobe
on simplicity and is always well groomed, she does not
overload with extras and non•essentials. For warm cli-
mates and longer stays. add silk, nylon or orlon dresses
and blouses. They are very light and perfect travelers.
With limitations on space and weight, the easy-wash-
ing, last-drying materials are the woman air traveler's
dream come true. Your wardrobe should a so include
a light raincoat, preferably of the crushable plastic
type. It is desirable to carry a large handbag or purse
with many compartments.
rollowing are some suggestions for vour wardrobe.
with plenty of luggage weight allowance left over to
carry home your loot without the worry of additional
baggage charges. As you may know, you are allowed
on economy-class flights and 66 lbs. on first-
class. You will have to pay excess charges on any
weight over these limits. Of course, you can send some
of your purchases home at reasonable rates by
